This regulation is crucial for maintaining protein homeostasis (proteostasis) under both normal (basal) and stress conditions. The mechanism involves the stabilization of the master transcriptional regulator of the heat shock response, HSF1.

This enhances the cell's capacity for protein folding, prevents the accumulation of misfolded or aggregated proteins, and promotes cell survival under proteotoxic stress.
biological_consequence: ATXN3 stabilizes the Heat Shock Factor-1 (HSF1) protein → The turnover of HSF1 is reduced, leading to higher cellular HSF1 levels → HSF1 binds more effectively to the Heat Shock Element (HSE) in the HSPA1A (Hsp70) gene promoter → Basal and stress-induced transcription of HSPA1A is increased → Cellular chaperone capacity is enhanced, improving protein folding and stress resilience.
